conclusion: Define variables: m_A, m_B for masses; N for normal force; f₁ for friction force between A and B; f₂ for friction force between A and ground.
Block B is pressed horizontally by an external force.
Horizontally, force F on B is balanced by N, so F = N.
Vertically, B is about to slide down, so upward static-friction force equals its weight: f₁ = μ₁ N = m_B g.
Block A is just about to slip on the ground.
Vertically, forces on A are its weight and ground’s normal reaction, so R = m_A g.
Horizontally, push from B (N) is balanced by limiting static friction on A from ground, f₂ = μ₂ R = μ₂ m_A g, so N = μ₂ m_A g.
Eliminate N between equations: μ₁ N = m_B g and N = μ₂ m_A g, leading to μ₁ μ₂ m_A g = m_B g.
Solve for mass ratio: m_A / m_B = 1 / (μ₁ μ₂).
Final answer: mass ratio m_A : m_B = 1 : (μ₁ μ₂) or m_A / m_B = 1 / (μ₁ μ₂).
